text:
A few important things you should know before traveling:  
* You should update the credit card company (Isracard) before your trip and let them know the destination country so that Isracard authorizes transactions abroad as well.
* Transaction confirmation messages are sent only via SMS to the mobile number registered with the credit card company. Therefore, it is advisable to update the credit card company with your current number before traveling.
* It is also recommended to remember the PIN code if you wish to withdraw funds.
* We also recommend reviewing your subscription plan before you travel as there are subscription plans that grant you benefits in foreign-currency transactions:
* In the ONE subscription plan and ONE PLUS subscription plan, no conversion fees will be charged for transactions made with the card.
* In ONE subscription plan and ONE PLUS subscription plan, only when withdrawing foreign currency abroad, a withdrawal fee of 2% of the withdrawal amount will be charged.
* On the ZERO subscription plan, a 2% commission is charged for foreign currency card transactions.
* On the ZERO subscription plan, a 3% fee will be charged for foreign currency ATM withdrawals, both in Israel and abroad.  
If you are on the ZERO subscription plan, you might want to consider upgrading to the ONE subscription plan through the [subscription plans page](https://app.tfd-bank.com/portfolio/settings/selectPlan) before you travel, to enjoy benefits abroad including foreign-currency transactions at with no exchange fees.

text: Cash withdrawal from an ATM belonging to any bank in Israel is free of withdrawal fees. Private ATMs companies charge their own fees, therefore, we recommend that you withdraw cash from bank-run ATMs connected to a branch in order to avoid these fees. It is not possible to withdraw money without a card. If you withdrew cash from an ATM with operating or third-party fees, then the fee is from the ATM operator, not ONE ZERO bank.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Card Usage and Services
metadata.Header 3: Cash withdrawal fees from ATMs in Israel using ONE ZERO credit card or debit card

text:
Handling failures in ATM withdrawals differs between ATMs in Israel and those abroad:
* Failures in withdrawals from ATMs in Israel – If you attempted to withdraw cash from an ATM in Israel and no cash was dispensed, but you still see a charge on your account, it is generally recommended to wait three business days for the funds to be credited back. If, after three business days, you have not received a refund, you can contact a [private banker](/actions/attach_agent) for further assistance. Please specify the ATM location and the withdrawal amount. If you used a debit card, the withdrawal may not be finalized and could appear as a pending transaction. In this case, you should wait 24 hours to ensure that the pending charge is removed.
* Failures in withdrawals from ATMs abroad – If you attempted to withdraw cash from an ATM abroad and the transaction failed, please contact [Isracard's customer service](https://digital.isracard.co.il/Abroad/lobby/Abroad/CustomerService/) for assistance.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Card Usage and Services

text:
The daily limit for cash withdrawal from ATM with ONE ZERO bank's Credit Card is different between withdrawals abroad and withdrawals inside Israel's borders:
* Withdrawal from ATM inside Israel borders with Credit Card - With your ONE ZERO bank credit card, you can withdraw cash up to 10,000 ILS per day from any ATM inside Israel borders. If you can not withdraw all 10,000 ILS at once, you can probably do it in two strokes. The daily withdrawal limit in one stroke on your credit card is 8,000 ILS. However, there is a fee for withdrawals from a private ATM that will be charged to the ATM company. We recommend that you withdraw cash from bank-run ATMs connected to a branch. Notice that there is no cash withdrawal without the bank card.
* Withdrawal from ATM abroad with a Credit Card - With your ONE ZERO bank credit card, your cash withdrawal limitation from ATM abroad is based on your credit card's lines of credit. As long as your credit card's lines of credit isn't completed, you can keep use it to withdraw cash from ATMs abroad.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Card Usage and Services
metadata.Header 3: Cash Withdrawals limit using ONE ZERO Credit Card

text:
The daily limit for cash withdrawal from ATM with ONE ZERO bank's Debit Card is different between withdrawals abroad and withdrawals inside Israel's borders:
* Withdrawal from ATM inside Israel borders with Debit Card - You can make purchases of up to 3,000 ILS per single transaction and to withdraws up to 5,000 ILS per day from any ATM inside Israel borders. For purchases exceeding 3,000 ILS on the debit card, therefore you will have to ask the merchant to split the bill into two payments.
* Withdrawal from ATM abroad with a Debit Card - You can withdraw up to 3,000 ILS per day from ATMs abroad, as long as there is remaining balance in your account.

If your credit card or debit card from Isracard is lost, stolen or damaged, you can request a replacement. Log in to your Isracard account and navigate to the Cards page. If you want to replace a card you received, there is a cost of 10 ILS for a regular order and 40 ILS for an immediate issuance for customers on the ZERO subscription plan. text: Google Pay is a payment service from Google, which operates Android devices, that allows you to make transactions and pay using your Android device. To set up Google Pay on your Android device, you need to download the Google Pay app from the Play Store. Once downloaded, open the app, enter the charge card information you would like to attach to your wallet (the card's 16-digit number, expiration date, and CVV), fill in your personal information and accept the terms of use, and enter the code received by text message from Isracard. You can also sign up for the Google Pay service using the Isracard app by opening the app, selecting "Sign up to Google Pay", choosing the desired card, and clicking Add to Google Pay. Google does not limit the number of cards that can be added to the Google Pay service. Isracard app or website has streamlined the process for linking your card to Google Pay directly from their platform, making it convenient for users. If you added more than one card to your Google Pay, the first card added will automatically be the default card and will open automatically on your next purchase. If you are interested in changing the default charge card, sign in to the Google Pay app, click on the desired card, and select "Set as default for contactless payment". Google Pay is the most secure service for transactions as your charge card information will never be transferred to the business venue when making a transaction. Google Pay requires strict identification when making a transaction, including biometric identification, fingerprint or facial recognition, PIN code, or password for maximum protection. If you lost an Android device with a charge card set up on Google Pay, you can contact Isracard at 03-6364400 for assistance.Suspending or removing the card from the service does not affect your physical card at all, and it will continue to operate unchanged. If your card still does not work even though it has been activated, contact a [private banker](/actions/attach_agent).

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Card Usage and Services
metadata.Header 3: Setting Up Google Pay on Android Devices

text: Apple Pay is the payment service from Apple that allows you to make secure purchases using Apple devices without contact (contactless) and on apps and websites that support Apple Pay. You can easily sign up for Apple Pay by watching the following [step by step video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nrBfsXHZO8s). If you watched the video and experienced a technical malfunction, you can contact a [private banker](/actions/attach_agent) who will be happy to resolve the issue for you. Apple allows up to 8 charge cards to be linked to the Apple Pay service. All charge cards linked to the Apple Pay app must belong to the same owner (with the same ID number). You can change this setting and select any other card to be the default card at any time. If you added more than one card to your Apple Pay, the first card added will automatically be the default card. To change the default card for Apple Pay, go to iPhone settings -> Wallet & Apple Pay -> select the desired card under "Transaction Defaults". Apple Pay is the most secure method for transactions as your charge card information will never be transferred to the business venue when making a transaction. Apple Pay requires strict identification when making a transaction, such as Face ID, Touch ID, PIN code, or password, for maximum protection.

If your card is charged before your salary is paid, causing discrepancies in payment and even an unarranged overdraft in your account, you have the option to change the card's billing day to a more convenient time. The existing billing days at ONE ZERO Bank are: 2, 10, 15, 20. It is important to know that the next billing date will appear for the first time after completion of the current month and completion of a full consecutive month. This means that if you choose to change your billing date on January 15, the change will only begin in March of that year. If you want to change the billing day, contact a [private banker](/actions/attach_agent). It is recommended to know your billing day and prepare for it every month. You can view your billing day on the [cards page](https://app.tfd-bank.com/portfolio/cards).

text:
If the card is cancelled, it will not be possible to reactivate it, unlike a frozen card, which can always be unfrozen. If your credit card has been blocked, usually due to a prolonged overdraft in the account, you can verify that the overdraft has been settled in full. After verifying, you can contact a [private banker](/actions/attach_agent) to examine the release of the block, if possible, assuming the unarranged overdraft has already been settled. You can temporarily block a card by freezing it through the app with the Freeze button under the Cards tab. The card will be blocked for 3 days. If the freeze is not canceled before the end of this time frame, the card will be automatically canceled, and a new card will be issued in its place. The card will be blocked for 3 days. You will need to activate the new card in the app. If the freeze is not canceled before the end of this time frame, the card will be automatically canceled, and a new card will be issued in its place. The new card will be sent via Israel Post in up to 7 business days. You will need to activate the new card in the app. Isracard's card cancellation days are Mondays and Thursdays.
Reactivating a blocked card depends on the type of block: if it is blocked and canceled, it cannot be reactivated at all. You can order a new card easily on the [cards page](https://app.tfd-bank.com/portfolio/cards) -> click on the Order button -> choose the Order a New Card option -> select credit card or debit card. You can temporarily block a card by selecting the card you want to block on cards page, clicking the three dots in the top-left corner of the page and choose "Freeze Card". The card will be blocked for 3 days. If the freeze is not canceled before the end of this time frame, the card will be automatically canceled, and a new card will be issued in its place. The new card will be sent via Israel Post in up to 7 business days. You will need to activate the new card in the app. Isracard's card cancellation days are Mondays and Thursdays. If you would like to reactivate a temporarily blocked card, you must make a reservation with a private banker by the cancellation day. To unfreeze a card that was temporarily frozen due to loss, you must use the Isracard app or contact an Isracard telephone service representative. If the card was frozen for reasons other than loss, you may contact a [private banker](/actions/attach_agent) for further assistance.

text:
If you notice unauthorized or fraudulent charges on your credit card statement, it is crucial to act promptly. Immediately report them to your credit card issuer for clarification. Your issuer might temporarily credit your account while conducting the clarification. In order to handle the issue, we would appreciate it if you could send us documents or any additional documentation that is relevant to the charge you did not identify. You can contact the merchant directly to request a refund according to their refund policy.
If the merchant is unable or unwilling to process the refund, you can initiate a [charge back through Isracard](https://digital.isracard.co.il/personalarea/Login/?returnUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fweb.isracard.co.il%2Fcardcancellation) for ONE ZERO cards or the card issuer of your external card for non-bank cards. Work closely with your issuer to resolve the dispute and ensure that any fraudulent activity is addressed promptly.
If needed, you can contact a [private banker](/actions/attach_agent) who will be happy to assist you on this issue.

text: Credit card charges appear 48 hours after the transaction and are deducted from your account on the billing day you set. On the other hand, debit card charges are deducted immediately after the transaction is executed. Transactions made on the debit card wait for final approval three business days until they are actually charged and therefore reserve funds from the checking account. Debit transactions made on the same day usually add up to one total charge. You can view the full details of the transactions on the Isracard website or app 48 hours after the execution of the transaction. metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Card Usage and Services
metadata.Header 3: Credit Card vs. Debit Card Transactions

text: If a card is issued by us, it is a bank card. Non-bank cards are cards issued outside the bank by various credit card companies and not through the bank. You can consider issuing a credit card in our app and enjoy the many benefits of having ONE ZERO bank card. There are non-bank cards, which can be ordered directly from the credit card company. It can be ordered from Isracard or other credit card companies for employees in organizations and workplaces that offers benefits for flying abroad, special conditions, branding and more. A non-bank card is not a bank account. More information about Isracard's corporate card can be found on [Isracard's corporate page](https://marketing.isracard.co.il/clubs/corporate/). Credit card companies provide non-bank services such as financial services, including credit card issuance, clearing services, loans, credit solutions and payment options. These companies provide world-class services to local credit card companies such as Isracard, Max and Cal. A non-bank card can be associated with any bank account you have and from which you want to deduct the card payment. Cards of this type have a line of credit set by the credit card company based on their judgment. On the card's billing day, an instruction is sent to download the charges received on the card to the bank account with which it is associated. For a non-bank card that charges your account with us, on the day the card is charged you must ensure that you have sufficient balance in the account in order to charge the authorization. On a bank card, the full account number appears on the back of the card at the bottom, below the card number. A bank card is a card issued by the credit card company that works with the bank and is debited from the account from which it was issued. This type of card has many advantages with affordable benefits and convenient viewing of data without the need to go to the credit card company's website. With a bank credit card, the credit line is set by the bank itself and not by the credit card company in order to optimize the adjustment to your needs. The bank works with Isracard for the benefit of bank cards. The credit cards issued by Isracard at the bank are debit cards and platinum credit cards. The charges and information on the credit cards are visible to the cardholder, who can view all the charges and their details in the bank application and at the credit card company.

text:
You can issue a non-bank card from other credit card companies and link it to your account using an account billing authorization. To do this, you can contact the appropriate credit card company to order the card. You can associate bank and non-bank cards with your account here, whose charges will be deducted from the account. A card belonging to another bank, cannot be associated with an account here. However, it can be transferred and all card data copied to the account here of your choice. In addition, you can link non-bank cards to an account by setting a billing authorization, and then viewing an installation certificate for the authorization to the institution. We allow our customers to link their non-bank credit cards to the app to make it convenient and easy for them to view charges.  
You can link non-bank cards on their provider websites:

text: To keep your credit card or debit card secure, don't share the card or its details. Keep your credit card in a safe place. The card security code (the CVV) should remain confidential and known only to you. Monitor transactions in your account, track your card's charges, activate notifications about card charges via text message or email, and check them frequently. When you make a purchase online, use only secure sites, look for a lock icon in the address bar to protect your credit card information. Keep the card's PIN code in a safe place and not with the card itself, but rather far from it. When using the PIN code, make sure that nobody nearby can see it, and at ATMs, cover the keypad when typing it in. If your card is lost or stolen, report it to your credit card company immediately to refuse its unauthorized use. If you wish to make a payment in installments for a charge already made to the card, this service can be provided by the credit card company for the number of installments you desire easily and conveniently on the [Isracard website/app](https://web.isracard.co.il/debtinstallments). In order to maintain our customers' accounts and ensure that the card is used only by the account holder, the courier is obligated to deliver only to them. The courier must identify the cardholder using an ID or driver's license, and only after verification (and delivery of the card) do we activate it. This ensures that no one else will be using the card.

metadata.Header 3: Suggestions for Keeping your card secure

text: ONE ZERO bank cards are personal and cannot be transferred or used by anyone else, so you cannot let anyone use your card, including your account partner. It is not possible to add an authorized user to your personal card. The ONE ZERO credit cards and debit cards supports 3D Secure (3DS), an information security protocol used to securely execute online transactions. This standard ensures the highest level of security for all parties to the transaction: the payee, the card issuer, and the intermediary between them.

By using the Google Pay service you benefit from a more secure payment with the most stringent transaction security assurance standards (the EMV global standard).

text: A large debit card transaction cannot be split into installments because a debit card does not have a debit card limit and is an instant debit. The debit card limit cannot be increased because a debit card does not have a limit, it can be used subject to a balance to be used on the account. Withdrawals can be made, subject to a sufficient balance, up to 5,000 ILS in total per day in Debit Card. Additionally, transactions can be conducted based on the account balance, up to 3,000 ILS per single transaction. For transactions exceeding 3,000 ILS, the Debit Card must be used multiple times. Currently, it is not possible to increase the credit withdrawal limit on the card beyond the existing limits based on the card type. Debit cards allow withdrawals of up to 5,000 ILS per day, while credit cards can be used for withdrawals up to 10,000 ILS in two installments. If you wish to make a payment in installments for a charge already made to the credit card, this service can be provided by the credit card company for the number of installments you desire easily and conveniently on the [Isracard website/app](https://web.isracard.co.il/debtinstallments). text: We currently offer two types of bank cards: a credit card and a debit card. The bank does not offer prepaid cards. The debit card, also known as a "direct" card, is limited to the available balance in the account. To determine which type of card is right for you, consider the objective of its use. If the card is for purchases and distribution of repayment into installments, a credit card might be suitable. text: ONE ZERO Bank offers a credit card line of credit feature that defines the maximum amount you can borrow, determined by factors like creditworthiness and income. The full amount of a purchase places a hold on the line of credit on your credit card. For example, if you bought a washing machine that costs 3,000 ILS in 10 installments, the entire amount will be considered used on the line of credit, and each month the usage will decrease by the amount of the monthly installment. text:
An unarranged overdraft in your account due to the card has consequences:  
1. A negative impact on your credit report.
2. Payment of interest on the checking account overdraft balance.  
If the overdraft is due to your credit card charge, it is required to settle the overdraft on the day the charge is displayed. The bank might freeze the card and even cancel it permanently in accordance with credit policy considerations. The bank might also return the charge due to non-sufficient funds, which is also expected to have a negative impact on your credit report. If you need assistance in finding a solution to avoid an unarranged overdraft due to the card, contact a [private banker](/actions/attach_agent). If your credit card has been canceled, it's usually due to a prolonged unarranged overdraft in the account. You should verify that the unarranged overdraft in the account has been fully arranged and contact our private bankers to examine the release of the block if it is possible. If the unarranged overdraft has already been arranged, contact a private banker to continue handling your request. If the credit card on your account has been canceled, you can examine the possibility of ordering a debit card instead.

text: A credit card is a card that allows you to make transactions using the card and consolidate the charge to a single date each month. To make a transaction using the card, you must ensure that the credit card line of credit is sufficient for the transaction. Transactions are billed automatically once a month from the checking account, freeing the billed amount from the line of credit. A debit card is a card that can be used for immediate payment. To pay for a particular product or service, the debit card requires an available balance in your account, which is the checking account balance that appears in the app. Future balances, such as a cheque that was deposited but has not yet been approved, cannot be used to carry out transactions. A debit card deducts charges immediately from your checking account. It is a card with no debit card limit and operates based on the balance in the account. Transactions and withdrawals can be made through it. The maximum amount for a single transaction or withdrawal is 3,000 ILS. If a higher amount is required, the card can be charged multiple times. Debit card charges are deducted from the account on an ongoing basis, but transactions made on the card wait three business days for final approval before they are actually charged, therefore, the amount of the transactions is reserved on the account. Debit transactions made on the same day usually add up to one total charge. You can view the full details of the transactions on the Isracard website/app 48 hours after the execution of the transaction.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Card Usage and Services
metadata.Header 2: Credit Cards vs. Debit Cards Similarities and Differences

text: Debit cards are regularly debited from the account, but transactions made on the card wait for final approval 3 business days until they are actually charged and therefore reserve funds from line of credit. Debit transactions made on the same day usually add up to one total charge. The full details of transactions can be viewed on the Isracard website/app 48 hours after the execution of the transaction. Your debit card deducts charges immediately from your checking account after the payment. Debit card charges are deducted from the account on an ongoing basis, but transactions made on the card wait 3 business days for final approval before they are actually charged, therefore, the amount on the account is reserved.

text: Credit card is a payment instrument issued by banks and credit card companies. It allows the customer to make purchases at businesses and pay at a later date, as well as to receive loans and cash withdrawals. The use of the card usually involves different fees and interest.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Card Usage and Services
metadata.Header 2: Credit Cards vs. Debit Cards Similarities and Differences

text:
* Revolving credit: A type of credit given to a customer when he does not pay the full balance on the card by the time he is charged. The unpaid amount rolls over to the next month, plus interest. This method allows the customer to spread the payment over time, but it can be expensive due to interest accumulation. Bank cards do not have this method of payment.
* Installment transactions: An option given to the customer to spread the payment for an expensive purchase into several (usually monthly) equal payments. Interest is often charged on future payments, but some promotions can be deployed interest-free. The spread of payments makes large purchases more accessible, but on the other hand may create a strain on the budget in the future.
* Abnormal Action Verification: A process designed to verify that an unusual action on the card (e.g., an extraordinarily high transaction or unusual location) is performed by the cardholder. Verification can be done through a phone call, a text message with a one-time code, or even a requirement for an ID card. The purpose of the process is to prevent misuse of the card in case of theft or fraud. This verification is most often carried out by the credit card company.
* Card Number (PAN): The primary credit card identification number, stamped on the physical card and encoded on the magnetic stripe or chip on it. The number includes up to 16 digits - 6 prefix digits identifying the issuer, up to 9 digits of the customer's unique account number, and last check digit. This number is used to verify and execute transactions in Israel and abroad.
* International credit card: A credit card that enables transactions abroad or in foreign currency, thanks to cooperation between credit card companies and international clearing networks such as Visa and MasterCard. Using an international card may save conversion fees, and is necessary for placing orders from foreign sites or while abroad.
* Credit threshold: the maximum amount that can be charged in a single transaction without obtaining special approval from the credit company. If the transaction amount exceeds the threshold, individual verification or authorization will be required before the charge is complete. The threshold is intended to protect the customer and the credit card company from exceptional or unauthorized charges, which may indicate theft or misuse of the card.
* Rechargeable credit card: A credit card that can be deposited (recharged) a sum of money in advance, and redeemed up to the amount charged only. This is a prepaid card and not credit in the usual sense, since it does not give the client the ability to accumulate debt. Such cards are useful for controlling expenses or making safe and limited payments in advance. The bank does not have a prepaid card.
* Virtual credit card: A credit card that does not physically appear on plastic, but exists digitally. The virtual card is specifically allocated for online shopping only, and its details are stored securely. This card can be used without fear of revealing the real card details, and it is easier to replace it in case of loss or fear of misuse.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text:
* Stock: A type of security that allows an issuing company to raise capital from investors on the stock exchange. In return for the money they pay for the investment in the share, investors receive part of the ownership of the company and thus become partners in it. With the money the company receives from the public, it can purchase equipment, recruit employees and develop its products, new and existing, in instruction to expand its operations. Some companies distribute dividends-that is, shareholders participate in its profits by receiving cash, according to the number of shares they hold.
* Option: A warrant grants the right to purchase a certain share at a predetermined price and postpone part of the payment to a later date. This right is limited in time - usually 2-5 years (Our bank will have foreign warrants but will not be opened for trading but as a product of a company event).
* Unlike mutual funds, which usually have a rate set only once each trading day, ETFs are regularly traded on the stock exchange, similar to the way stocks are traded with ask and bid, although some of them have an option to trade like mutual funds at the end of the day.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading
metadata.Header 3: Maintain, Depository, Management and Custody Fees

text: In most of the Israeli banks, management fees are charges applied by investment managers for overseeing a client's investment portfolio. Typically expressed as a percentage of the assets under management (AUM), these fees cover the managers' expertise, time, and operational costs. In addition to management fees, banks often charge custody fees, which are fees for holding and safeguarding the securities in the client's portfolio. Both types of fees are common in various investment vehicles, including mutual funds and investment accounts. These fees directly impact the net returns of investors, making it essential for clients to understand these costs when evaluating the overall performance and potential returns of their investments. In ONE ZERO bank, non of our clients is being charged for management fees or custody fees.

text: Third-party expenses incurred for securities transactions encompass both buying and selling expenses. These expenses are subject to variation depending on factors such as the type of security and the jurisdiction in which the transaction occurs. When executing transactions, these charges will be reflected either in the designated foreign currency account or the ILS checking account, depending on the customer's specified preference at the time of instruction submission. It's important to note that these expenses represent the actual costs borne by the bank during the execution of instructions. Consequently, the bank is unable to provide discounts or waive these charges. As such, customers should anticipate these expenses as part of their overall transaction costs and plan accordingly when engaging in securities trading activities. Please note that third-party expenses cannot be discounted or waived, as they represent the actual costs incurred during transaction execution. Expenses related to transactions involving third parties, such as brokers or the SEC, will be charged accordingly and reflected in either foreign currency or ILS checking accounts, depending on the client's preference at the time of instruction. Third party expenses may change from time to time (according to changes in taxes, levies, changes in law in each country, etc.). Active funds are not charged third-party expenses.

text: In securities trading, Long and Short are common concepts representing two distinct investment strategies. A Long position involves buying a security with the expectation that its value will increase over time, allowing the investor to profit from the price appreciation. Conversely, a Short position entails selling a security that the investor does not currently own, with the intention of buying it back later at a lower price. This strategy is based on the belief that the security's price will decline, enabling the investor to repurchase it at a reduced cost and pocket the price difference as profit. Our platform supports Long trading, enabling you to buy securities for investment purposes. However, please note that while some ETFs offer inverse exposure, we do not currently support short trading directly. Short exposure can be achieved by purchasing ETFs with inverse exposure.

In reverse splits, it's the last known rate multiplied by the ratio, while in stock splits, it's divided by the ratio.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text: Splits in the context of corporate actions refer to events where the number of shares held by shareholders changes, often without altering the total value of their holdings. One type of split is a reverse split, where the number of shares outstanding is reduced, usually to increase the stock price. This can occur when a company's shares have depreciated significantly, and a higher price per share is desired. In contrast, a stock split involves dividing each existing share into multiple shares, effectively increasing the number of outstanding shares. Stock splits are typically done to make shares more affordable to investors and increase liquidity in the market. Both types of splits can impact shareholder equity and the overall perception of the company in the market.

text: Israeli residents are subject to a 25% tax withholding for capital gains on transactions. Additionally, the US Securities and Exchange Commission charges a fee for security sale execution.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text:
* Aggregate Mutual Fund does not distribute its profits to the participation unit holders as a dividend. The fund accumulates its profits and reinvests them in additional assets
* Profit-Sharing Fund does not accumulate its profits and distributes them as dividends to the holders of the participation units.
* Exempt Mutual Fund does not pay tax on its income, and therefore the investor in the fund will pay tax on real capital gains. A capital loss arising from the redemption of a unit in an exempt fund may be offset against capital gains tax on the sale of Israeli negotiable securities or on the redemption of units in exempt mutual funds.
* Liable Mutual Fund pays tax directly to the tax authorities according to the tax rates applicable to individuals. As a result, the capital gain to the investor generated at the time of redemption of the unit is exempt from capital gains tax, as is the dividend. A capital loss suffered in the redemption of a liable mutual fund does not allow for offsetting capital gains on other securities.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text: Tracking funds are a specific type of mutual fund whose purpose is to track a certain index, on a best effort basis, meaning - it does not commit to it. Most often, a tracking fund buys the assets that make up the index according to their weight but can also be exposed through derivatives or through investment in other tracking instruments (mainly abroad). Some funds may be exposed to currency, USD for example, and can cause a situation in which the index rises and the dollar USD falls, thereby cumulatively the return can be lower than expected or even negative. On the other hand, a currency-neutralized fund will only be exposed to changes in the index but carries within it the costs of neutralizing a currency. Tracking funds can be traded at ONE ZERO Bank.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text:
These are types of tracking funds:
* Reverse exposure fund – Type of mutual fund whose investment policy states that its purpose is to achieve results that are negatively correlated with the rate of change in its reference asset. The reverse exposure is achieved by short selling the shares (short) or derivatives.
* Foreign Investment Fund – This is an exempt mutual fund with at least 90% of its investments in assets denominated in or linked to a particular foreign currency, and it defines itself as a main IMF. When calculating real capital gain in such a fund, a change in the exchange rate of the selected main currency is taken into account and not a change in the consumer price index.
* Kosher Fund – Type of mutual fund managed in accordance with the rules of Jewish law. The fund invests only in companies and assets that meet halachic criteria, such as a prohibition on investing in companies that profit from interest.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text: Active fund is a type of mutual fund in which the fund manager has discretion in choosing assets, unlike index-tracking funds where the fund manager buys shares of a particular index.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text:
These are types of tracking funds:
* Specialized fund – Type of active mutual fund in which most of its assets (at least 75%) are exposed to a particular investment channel. For example, a fund in which 75 percent of the fund is obligated to be invested in government bonds.
* Flexible fund – Type of active mutual fund that is not bound by a particular investment policy and is entitled to invest in any investment channel at the discretion of the fund manager, within the sector limits defined in the prospectus. For example, a fund that invests in indexed bonds as well as USD bonds and stocks.
* Leveraged fund – Type of active mutual fund whose exposure to stocks, foreign exchange or bonds can exceed, in absolute value, 200% of the net value of the fund's assets. A leveraged fund operates extensively in derivatives, short sales, etc. Investing in this fund involves higher risk than investing in other funds, and management fees are usually higher. For example, a leveraged fund has 2x, if the index has risen by 10%, the fund will strive to yield a return of 2 times, and if the index falls by 10%, then the fund is expected to decline by approximately 20%.
* Money Market Fund - Type of active mutual fund that invests in short-term, high-quality financial instruments like certificates of deposit, short-term government bonds, and commercial paper. It aims to provide a safe investment option with high liquidity and low risk, often maintaining a stable value per share.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text:
* Limit instruction (LMT): A type of instruction where the investor sets a specific price limit for buying or selling a security. It ensures that the transaction occurs at the specified price or better.
* Market instruction (MKT): An instruction to buy or sell a security at the current market price. It guarantees execution but does not specify the price, potentially resulting in a different price than expected.
* Mutual Funds instruction (KRN): A unique instruction for buying or selling a mutual fund. The execution will occur at the end of the day according to the "שעה ייעודה" of the mutual fund.
* Conditional instructions: Also known as trigger or stop instructions, these are instructions injected into the market to execute when predefined conditions are met. They allow traders to automate transactions based on price movements.
* Ask Price: The lowest price at which a seller is willing to sell a security. It represents the price a buyer must pay to acquire the security.
* Available Trading Balance: The purchasing power available in the trading account, including checking account balances, overdraft limits, and unsettled transaction amounts. It determines the amount a trader can invest.
* Pre-Market Trading: The period before the official market opening hours during which traders can execute instructions. It provides opportunities to react to overnight developments and news.
* Over the Counter (OTC) Trading: A method of trading securities directly between parties outside of formal exchanges. It offers flexibility but might lack transparency compared to exchange trading.
* BID: The demand price (BID) is the highest price at which buyers are willing to buy.
* ASK: The Ask price is the lowest price at which sellers are willing to sell a stock or other investment asset.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text:
Other terms:  
* Initial Public Offering (IPO): The process of offering shares of a private company to the public for the first time. It allows companies to raise capital by selling ownership stakes. It provides avenues for diversified investment portfolios and capitalizing on emerging companies. IPOs are often issued by younger, smaller companies seeking capital to expand, but they can also be done by large privately-owned companies looking to become publicly traded.
* Secondary Offering: A sale of new or closely held shares of a company that has already made an initial public offering (IPO). Usually, these shares are sold by company insiders or major shareholders, not by the company itself.
* Stock Exchange and Trading Fund (ETF): A type of investment fund traded on stock exchanges, much like stocks. ETFs hold a basket of securities such as stocks, commodities, or bonds, and often track an index. They offer low expense ratios and high liquidity compared to mutual funds.
* Mutual Funds: An investment vehicle that pools money from many investors to purchase securities such as stocks, bonds, or other assets. Mutual funds are managed by professional fund managers and offer investors a diversified portfolio and economies of scale.
* Financial Statement Analysis: The process of analyzing financial statements to evaluate the financial health and performance of a company. It helps investors make informed decisions.
* Understanding Conditional instructions: Also known as trigger or stop instructions, these are instructions injected into the market to execute when predefined conditions are met. They allow traders to automate transactions based on price movements.
* Available Trading Balance: The purchasing power available in the trading account, including checking account balances, overdraft limits, and unsettled transaction amounts. It determines the amount a trader can invest.
* "English Opening": A circuit breaker mechanism applied during the pre-opening phase of trading to halt trading in certain situations. It ensures orderly trading and prevents extreme price movements.
* P/B and P/E Ratios: Financial ratios used to evaluate the valuation of a company's stock. The Price-to-Book (P/B) ratio compares the market value of a company to its book value, while the Price-to-Earnings (P/E) ratio compares the stock price to earnings per share.
* Market Volatility and Interest Rates: Market volatility refers to the degree of variation in trading prices over time. Interest rates influence borrowing costs, investment returns, and overall economic activity.
* Subscription Plans and Fees: Different subscription plans offer varying benefits and fees for trading services. They cater to the needs and preferences of different types of traders.
* 52-week high: Refers to the highest price at which a security, such as a stock, has traded during a one-year time period, providing insights into its historical performance and potential volatility.
* Form 867: A reporting document used to declare profits and losses from savings accounts, securities (including interest), and dividends, ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements and accurate tax reporting.
* International Securities Identification Number (ISIN): A unique code comprising 12 letters and numbers, serving as a universal identifier for specific securities. This standardized system facilitates efficient trading, clearing, and settlement processes across global markets, enhancing transparency and accessibility for investors.
* Futures Contract: A standardized legal agreement to buy or sell a particular commodity, currency, or other instrument at a predetermined price at a specified time in the future. Futures are used for hedging price risk and for speculative trading.
* Stock Exchange: A marketplace where stocks, bonds, commodities, and other securities are traded. Examples include the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), NASDAQ, and London Stock Exchange (LSE).
* Investment Portfolio: A collection of assets including stocks, bonds, commodities, cash, and cash equivalents, as well as closed-end funds and ETFs, owned by an individual or an institution.
* Equity: The value of an asset less the amount of all liabilities on that asset. It can also refer to a corporation's common stock and represent the residual value of a company after subtracting liabilities from assets.
* Earnings Per Share (EPS): The portion of a company's profit allocated to each outstanding share of common stock. It serves as an indicator of a company's profitability.
* Return: The gain or loss of an investment over a specified period, expressed as a percentage of the investment's initial cost.
* Duration: A measure of the sensitivity of the price of a bond to a change in interest rates, expressed in years.
* Alpha: A measure of an investment's performance compared to a benchmark, such as the S&P 500. It represents the excess return of an investment relative to the return of a benchmark index.
* Balance Sheet: A financial statement that reports a company's assets, liabilities, and shareholders' equity at a specific point in time.
* Beta: A measure of the volatility or systematic risk of a security or portfolio compared to the market as a whole. Beta indicates how the value of a security responds to fluctuations in the overall market.
* Sharpe Ratio: A ratio used to measure the risk-adjusted return of an investment. It is calculated by subtracting the risk-free rate from the return of the investment and then dividing the result by the standard deviation of the investment's returns.
* Standard Deviation: A statistical measure of the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values. In finance, standard deviation is applied to the annual rate of return of an investment to measure its volatility
* Diversification: A risk management strategy that mixes a wide variety of investments within a portfolio, aiming to minimize the impact of any one security on overall portfolio performance.
* Leverage: The use of borrowed money to increase the potential return of an investment. Leverage also increases the potential downside risk in case the investment moves against the investor.
* Price History: A record of the trading prices of an asset over time, often presented in a graphical format. Price history helps investors and analysts assess an asset's past performance and make predictions about its future direction.
* Investment Policy: A set of guidelines, rules, and procedures that govern how an investor's portfolio should be managed. It includes the investor's goals, risk tolerance, asset allocation, and investment constraints
* Price-to-Earnings Ratio (P/E Ratio): The ratio of a company's share price to the company's earnings per share. The P/E ratio is used for valuing companies and to find out whether they are overvalued or undervalued.
* Market Capitalization: The total USD value of all of a company's outstanding shares, calculated by multiplying the total number of a company's outstanding shares by the current market price of one share.
* Book Value: The value at which an asset is carried on a balance sheet. For assets, the value is based on the original cost of the asset less any depreciation, amortization, or impairment costs made against the asset
* Shortage of Supply: A situation in the market where there are not enough products or services being offered to meet the demand of buyers. This often leads to a price increase
* Excess Demand: An economic situation where the demand for a product in the market exceeds the available supply. This often leads to a price increase
* Foreign Security: A security issued by a foreign government or corporation. These can offer diversification benefits but also carry risks like currency fluctuations and political instability
* Derivatives: Derivatives are financial instruments whose value is derived from another asset. There are two main types of derivatives: options and futures. These derivatives allow buyers or sellers to protect their investment from increases or decreases in the price of a particular asset, but also as a substitute for a leveraged investment in the underlying asset.
* Fractional shares: Fractional Share is a part of an entire share of a company that is traded on the stock exchange. Buying a fractional share means buying less than an entire share of company, which allows investment of amount that is smaller than the amount of the entire share. At the moment, it is not possible to buy fractions of shares through ONE ZERO Bank's securities trading system.
* SEC fees: SEC fees attached to securities who are listed at the US stock market. The fee is based on the volume of shares traded and applies to the sale of stocks, but not the purchase of stocks.
* ETF: ETF is an acronym for Exchange-Traded Fund, meaning: exchange-traded fund. It is a pooled security that can be bought and sold like an individual stock. ETF's allow you access to many stocks across various industries. ETF's can be structured to track anything from the price of a commodity to an index.

text:
These are common concepts of Israeli securities mutual funds:
* Fund Manager – A company authorized to manage the fund and operates in accordance with the fund agreement signed between the manager and the trustee and published to the public.
* Trustee – holds the fund's assets in trust for investors and at the same time supervises the fund manager, the fund's conduct and its compliance with the conditions of law and prospectus.
* Management fees – the mutual fund management fees charged for managing the mutual fund. Management fees are published in annual terms but are charged daily according to the proportion of the value of the fund's assets. Management fees are embodied in the price of the fund, meaning they are not collected directly from the client's account, but it can affect on the fund yield.
* Trustee fees – The mutual fund trustee's fees like management fees, is collected daily according to the proportion of the value of the fund's assets. Trust fees are embodied in the principal price, meaning they are not collected directly from the client's account, but it can affect on the fund yield.
* Distribution fee – payment paid by the fund manager to TASE members (banks, investment houses) through which units of managed funds are shift only. For tracking funds, there is no shift fee.
* Rate of add – a one-time payment that is added to the price of the fund units at the time of purchase and is calculated as a percentage of the purchase amount. The addition rate is paid by the investor directly to the fund manager. Exist at part of the funds.
* Purchase price - total assets of the fund (net) plus sales fees divided by the amount of units in the fund, multiplied by the rate of add.
* Redemption price – total assets of the fund (net) minus sales fees divided by the amount of units in the fund.
* "שעה ייעודה" – mutual funds are not traded continuously but once a day by the hour of its designation, which is published in the fund's prospectus. The designated time is the end time during which a request for the creation or redemption of the Fund's units can be broadcast.
* Open-end fund -diversified portfolio of pooled investor money that can issue unlimited shares. The fund manager sells shares directly to investors and redeems them as well. These shares are priced daily based on their net asset value. The transactions are carried out through a distributor, the transactions are given during the trading day, but the creation/redemption operation is actually done once a day, at the end of the trading day. When requesting the creation/redemption of units of an open mutual fund, it is not possible to know at what price the transaction will be executed.
* Closed-end fund - type of mutual fund that issues a fixed number of shares through one initial public offering to raise capital for its initial investments. Its shares can then be bought and sold on a stock exchange, but no new shares will be created, and no new money will flow into the fund. Like many mutual funds, a closed-end fund has a manager overseeing the portfolio and actively buying, selling, and holding assets. Similar to stocks and ETFs, its shares fluctuate in price throughout the trading day.

* Tender Offer - A public solicitation to all shareholders requesting that they tender their stock for sale at a specific price during a certain time.

text:
Most Commonly Known Index Types at US market:
* S&P 500: This index is comprised of the 500 largest companies on all U.S. stock exchanges. The weight of each company in the index is determined by its market capitalization. This index is considered to represent the US economy well and is a reflection of it.
* Nasdaq Index: This index consists of all shares traded on the NASDAQ stock exchange. The weight of each share in the index is determined by its market capitalization. In other words, the higher the company's market capitalization, the greater its impact on the index (similar to the method of calculating the MAUF index). Most of the companies traded on NASDAQ are engaged in high-tech (communications, computers, internet, etc.).
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average: Composed of the 30 largest companies on the New York Stock Exchange. The companies represent a variety of industries. The value of an index is determined by a mathematical average of stock prices regardless of market value. That is, the higher the price of a particular share, the greater its weight in the index.

text: A stop-limit instruction is a conditional trade executed over a set time frame that combines the features of a stop instruction with those of a limit instruction, used primarily to mitigate risk. It is related to other types of instructions, including limit instructions (an instruction to either buy or sell a specified number of shares at a given price or better) and stop-on-quote instructions (an instruction to either buy or sell a security after its price has surpassed a specified point). The expiry date of a stop-limit instruction is defined by the user.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text:
A stop-limit instruction requires setting two price points: the stop price and the limit price. First, set the stop price, which is the price at which you want the trade to be triggered. If the price of the security (for a BUY instruction) reaches the stop price or (for a SELL instruction) falls below or equals the stop price, the instruction limit will be sent to the market once the trigger has been activated.
Next, set the limit price. The limit price is the price at which you want to buy or sell the security. This price is used to limit the maximum price you will pay or the minimum price you will receive for the trade. A time frame must also be set during which the stop-limit instruction is considered executable.
The stop-limit instruction will be executed at a specified price or better after a given stop price has been reached. Once the stop price is reached, the stop-limit instruction becomes a limit instruction to buy or sell at the limit price or better.
However, it's important to note that there is a risk the instruction may not be executed. Therefore, it's crucial to carefully consider market conditions and your trading objectives before placing a stop-limit instruction.
Trading with the Stop-Limit instruction is available through the [securities page](https://app.tfd-bank.com/portfolio/securities).

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading
metadata.Header 3: Explanation About Using The stop-limit Instruction

text: Modifying or canceling a Stop-Limit instruction is possible as long as it has not been executed. It is important to monitor your instruction and make adjustments as needed based on market conditions. The stop-limit instruction would remain open until the limit price is met or the instruction expires.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text: In a Stop-Loss (stop market) instruction, when the price triggers, a market instruction is transmitted, whereas in a Stop-Limit instruction, a limit instruction is transmitted. Stop-Loss and Stop-Limit instructions can provide different types of protection for both long and short investors. Stop-Loss instructions offer more guarantee of execution, while Stop-Limit instructions guarantee the price. As of today, the bank does not support the Stop-Loss instruction type.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text:
* Controlled Price Execution: With a stop-limit instruction, it is possible to set a limit price higher or lower than the stop price, depending on whether you are buying or selling. This control ensures you enter or exit trades at preferred prices, minimizing unfavorable fills.
* Effective Risk Management: Setting a stop price helps limit potential losses if the market moves against you. Meanwhile, specifying a limit price prevents execution at undesirable prices, thereby managing risk effectively.
* Automated Execution: Once placed, the stop-limit instruction is automatically sent to the market when the stop price is reached. This automation allows for hands-free execution, ideal for traders preferring a more passive approach or unable to monitor the market continuously.
* Versatile Trading Tool: Suitable for various strategies such as day trading, swing trading, and position trading, stop-limit instruction provide flexibility to enter or exit trades, catering to different trading styles and objectives.

metadata.Header 1: ONE ZERO Bank Guide on Securities Trading

text:
* Execution Control with Potential Risks: While a stop-limit instruction enables control over trade entry and exit prices, there is no assurance of execution. If the market moves swiftly and fails to reach your limit price, your instruction may remain unfilled, particularly problematic in volatile markets with rapid price fluctuations.
* Vulnerability to Price Gaps: Stop-limit instructions may not safeguard against price gaps, where a security's price leaps from one level to another without trades in between. If your limit price isn't met during a price gap, you risk being filled at a significantly worse price than anticipated.
* Psychological Pressure: Triggered stop-losses can tempt traders to hold positions in hopes of market reversals, leading to emotional decision-making and potential harm to overall trading strategies.
* Complexity Compared to Other Instructions: Setting up and executing stop-limit instructions can be more intricate than market or limit instructions. Traders must grasp the nuances of setting stop and limit prices and comprehend how these factors interact within the market environment.
